headline: Taiwan Tech Gains China Access
summary: Taiwan will lower investment barriers for its flat-panel and electronic chip makers to do business in China, while an official said lower barriers for brokerage firms and insurance companies are likely to be approved.

headline: Storm Strikes
summary: Snow, wind and slush hounded East Coast commuters early Wednesday as blizzard warnings from Baltimore to New York City heralded the second major snowstorm in less than a week for the region.

summary: Low-cost airlines are here to stay, says Ajay Singh, director of India's SpiceJet, in an interview with Jyoti Malhotra for The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Francis Fukuyama: What Became of the 'Freedom Agenda'?
summary: President Obama can avoid his predecessor's mistakes without alienating the people of countries like Iran.

headline: Stocks Slip as Fed Outlines Exit
summary: Stocks edged lower as Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke laid out plans to eventually raise some borrowing costs.

headline: Former Texas Rep. Charlie Wilson Dies
summary: Former U.S. Rep. Charlie Wilson, who helped lead a secret effort during the 1980s to funnel U.S. aid to Afghans fighting the Soviet Army, died Wednesday at a hospital in Texas. He was 76.

headline: Prudential, Allstate Swing to Profits
summary: Prudential Financial's financial-services business and Allstate both swung to a fourth-quarter profit. But while Allstate bested analysts' expectations, Prudential disappointed.

headline: NAB's AXA Bid Draws Worries
summary: Australia's competition regulator suggested it is more concerned by the impact on competition if NAB proceeds with a takeover of AXA Asia Pacific than it is by a rival bid by wealth manager AMP.

headline: TARP Stake in CIT Is Wiped Out
summary: U.S. taxpayers' $2.3 billion stake in CIT has officially been wiped out, according to a Treasury report.

headline: Greek Civil Servants Strike
summary: Thousands of Greek civil servants walked off the job to protest a wage freeze and cuts in bonuses, with unions vowing further strike action over the Socialist government's austerity plan to solve a debt crisis that has roiled markets around the world.

headline: Minor Earthquake Strikes Near Chicago
summary: The quake had a magnitude of 3.8 could be felt as far away as Ohio and Missouri. No damage or injuries were reported.

headline: BHP Billiton Sticks to Its Guns
summary: Investors are grumbling that BHP Billiton isn't spending more on dividends and share buybacks. But CEO Marius Kloppers is doing the right thing.

headline: Micron Deal Will Pressure Two Rivals
summary: The deal to acquire Numonyx for $12.7 billion will boost Micron's presence in the competitive flash-chip market.

summary: Why have we encouraged people to put all their savings in one asset?

summary: My name is Straw Man, and I've got a direct pipeline to the Oval Office.

headline: Boston Scientific Loss Narrows
summary: Boston Scientific posted a narrower fourth-quarter loss despite a big settlement payment, but the medical-device maker unveiled steps to shake up management and streamline operations.

headline: We've Enabled Castro, Not Hurt Him
summary: As I read your editorial "Castro's Hostage Politics" (Feb. 6), I had to check the date on my paper to make sure I was in 2010 and not 1960. Over 50 years later you still promote the same rhetoric that has garnered absolutely nothing for the people of Cuba or for the U.S. in its relationship with the island

headline: All Society Could Use Some Military Virtues
summary: Regarding In Bret Stephens's  "Gays in the Militaries" (Global View, Feb. 9): Our pursuit of happiness must be tempered by considerations of duty, honor and country.

headline: Activision Posts Wider Loss
summary: Activision Blizzard reported a wider fourth-quarter loss on a $240.9 million write-down of assets and echoed a downbeat outlook given by rival videogame maker Electronic Arts.

headline: More IPO Debuts Postponed
summary: Travel-reservations company Travelport postponed its $1.77 billion offering on the London Stock Exchange, while Graham Packaging again lowered the projected price for its offer on the NYSE.

headline: Fall 2010 NY Fashion Week Preview
summary: New York fashion week starts on Thursday and with it, a set of new Fall 2010 collections. Here's a sneak peek at some of the looks designers will debut.

headline: EU Membership Just Got Tougher
summary: Greece's woes could make it harder for other countries to gain admittance into the European Union, and the fiscally prudent may become less enthusiatic about the euro.

headline: A Housewife Inventor Builds a Homespun Empire
summary: Entrepreneur Debbie Meyer cleans up with kitchen gadgets – and leaves the $100 million mark in the dust.

headline: Europe Weighs Rescue Plan for Greece
summary: Germany is considering a plan with its European Union partners to offer Greece and other troubled euro zone members loan guarantees in an effort to calm market fears of a default.

headline: Strong Stocks Buoy Oil Prices
summary: Crude oil futures rose in light trade, after stronger European equities helped oil prices pare earlier losses.

headline: Fund Streak Hits 47th Week
summary: Long-term mutual funds had net inflows for the 47th straight week on continued strength for bond funds, which more than offset outflows in stock funds.

headline: Treasurys Retreat After Auction
summary: Treasury prices fell after a 10-year note auction drew tepid demand and as Bernanke provided more details about how the Fed will eventually tighten monetary policy.

headline: Ericsson, Alcatel Tapped for AT&T Wireless Network
summary: The deal marks another key win for the two companies as equipment makers fight to win the first major orders for Long Term Evolution, or LTE, a fourth-generation wireless network technology that offers higher traffic speeds than older standards.

headline: U.S. Trade Gap Widens
summary: The U.S. trade deficit widened in December, suggesting that the economy didn't grow quite as strongly in the fourth quarter as first thought, but also indicating that global trade is accelerating as the world emerges from a deep recession.

headline: Greece Strikes and Protests Begin
summary: A civil servants' strike grounded flights and shut down public services across Greece on Wednesday, as labor unions mounted their first major challenge to austerity measures in the debt-plagued country.

headline: Ivy Deals Are Well Received in Muni Market
summary: In an otherwise quiet issuance week, Yale University sold more than $500 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds. Despite the university's recent sizable investment decline and increased debt load, the deal has been fairly well received by the municipal bond market.

headline: Vietnam to Devalue Dong 3.4%
summary: Vietnam will devalue its currency for the second time in less than three months, as it fights a large trade deficit, high inflation and a shortage of U.S. dollars needed to keep the financial sector humming.

headline: Becton Part Isn't Linked to Death
summary: The medical-device maker said the recently recalled part that hospitals use to deliver fluids intravenously wasn't responsible for a death it was investigating for possible links to the device.

headline: Portugal Sells Bond asEuro Debt Markets Strengthen
summary: Hopes that the European Union will aid troubled euro zone members helped Portugal get more than four times the orders needed to raise $4.13 billion in a closely watched 10-year bond sale.

headline: Tea Party Heroine
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAIL  Former Fox News contributor Angela McGlowan hinted that she would be running for Congress in Mississippi.

headline: China Charges Rio Tinto Workers
summary: State media said charges include taking bribes from Chinese steel firms and violating commercial secrets laws.

headline: Omnicom Profit Falls 15%
summary: Omnicom said profit fell 15% in the fourth quarter as the industry continued to suffer from muted advertising spending.

headline: RBS Nears Sale of Some Sempra Assets
summary: RBS is near a deal to sell the non-North American operations of a joint business with Sempra Energy to J.P. Morgan.

headline: EU Probes Air Freight Firms
summary: The European Commission said it has sent formal antitrust charges to air-freight-forwarding companies on suspicion they operated a cartel on several global routes.

headline: New Sept. 11 Photos Released
summary: Newly released aerial photos of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack on the World Trade Center show the towers coming down from a dramatic new angle.

headline: Vietnam Central bank to Devalue Dong 3.4%
summary: This will be the second devaluation of the Vietnamese dong in three months. The central bank shaved 5% off the value of the dong on Nov. 27.

headline: Firms Eye Kabel Deutschland
summary: At least five private-equity firms have submitted or are in the process of submitting bids for German cable operator Kabel Deutschland.

headline: King: BOE Keeps Options Open
summary: Bank of England governor Mervyn King said it is far too soon to rule out further monetary easing through asset purchases, as the outlook for the economy remains highly uncertain.

headline: It's Baidu's Battle to Lose
summary: With earnings up strongly year-to-year and its main competitor in China in limbo, life seems pretty good for Internet company Baidu.

headline: Jobs Bill Likely to Be Delayed in Senate
summary: The Senate will likely delay voting on the $80 billion jobs package after Republicans balked at Democratic efforts to push the measure through the chamber by week's end.

headline: BHP Beats Forecasts; Outlook Cautious
summary: BHP Billiton's net profit for the half was $6.14 billion, but the miner gave a cautious outlook about short-term commodities demand. Revenue fell 17%.

headline: Tremors in Sichuan
summary: The political effects of the earthquake are still being felt.

headline: EU Debates IMF Role for Greece
summary: There is growing debate among European Union policy makers over whether a homegrown remedy to Greece's fiscal crisis makes more sense than help from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Hedge Funds Brace for European Showdown
summary: The European Union has the potential to shoot itself in the foot with its Alternative Investment Fund Manager directive for hedge funds, now under debate.

headline: Kingfisher Airlines to Operate New Overseas Flights
summary: Kingfisher Airlines got the Indian government's approval to start seven new international flights, which will double its overseas operations.

headline: German Bund Sale Tops Expectations
summary: Germany's auction of its 10-year benchmark federal bond attracted strong demand, with German issues benefiting from residual economic fears.

headline: Japan's 10-Year Yield Eases
summary: A stronger yen rekindled concern over Japan's export-driven economy, pushing investors into the country's government bonds.

headline: Jones Apparel Loss Narrows
summary: Jones Apparel posted a significantly narrower loss on smaller write-downs as the New York clothing retailer's core business improved.

headline: Banks Fuel a Rally in Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded 1.2%, as investors picked up beaten-down Chinese banks and local property developers.

headline: WNS Holdings Says Billing Rates Have Stabilized
summary: Indian business process outsourcing company WNS Holdings has started seeing stable billing rates in a sign that the worst of the economic downturn is over.

headline: DLF Plans Bond Sale to Retire High-Cost Debt
summary: DLF, India's biggest property developer by sales, plans to raise up to 10 billion rupees ($215 million) through a bond sale by the end of February and use the proceeds to replace high-cost debt, senior company executives said.

headline: Infrastructure Investments Key to Sustain India's Growth
summary: India needs heavy investments to mend its creaking infrastructure to help sustain economic growth that may exceed the government's 7.2%estimate for the fiscal year ending March 31, the finance minister said.

headline: Wipro Eyes Buys in Telecom, Healthcare
summary: Wipro, India's third-largest software exporter by revenue, is looking at acquisitions to plug gaps in its services offerings, said IT services division joint chief executive, Girish Paranjpe.

headline: Palmer: China Deal is Binding
summary: But Australian resources developer Clive Palmer said that some details of a coal sales agreement unveiled last weekend are yet to be finalized.

headline: Sri Lanka Leader Calls Early Vote
summary: Sri Lankan President Mahinda Rajapaksa dissolved the country's parliament Tuesday, making way for a national election two months earlier than scheduled.

headline: Bank of India Defers Overseas Bond Issue
summary: Bank of India has deferred an overseas bond issue due to volatile market conditions, three people familiar with the matter said, becoming the second Indian lender in less than a week to end an international roadshow without a deal.

headline: Washington Builds a Snow Mountain
summary: Running out of places to put the huge volume of white stuff, Washington decides to build a snow mountain.

headline: S&P Cuts BofA, Citi Outlook
summary: S&P lowered its outlook for Bank of America and Citigroup to negative, saying it's unsure whether the U.S. would be willing to give additional support to the banks in a way that benefits  ebtholders.

headline: Micron to Buy Numonyx in $1.27 Billion Stock Deal
summary: Micron Technology said it will pay about $1.27 billion in stock to acquire Numonyx, a spinoff from Intel and STMicroelectronics that adds new varieties of memory chips to Micron's portfolio.

headline: D.C. Braces for More Snow
summary: Washington and Mid-Atlantic states prepared for a second big storm that could leave as much as 14 inches of new snow in Washington by Wednesday night.

headline: Greece Unveils Austerity Measures
summary: Greece, facing pressure from both financial markets and union protests, announced measures to cap public-sector salaries and reform the country's tax code in a bid to fix its finances.

headline: Online Cobblers Fix Shoes From Afar
summary: Shoe-repair shops are increasingly rare, but a number of online cobblers are stepping up to repair footwear by mail.

headline: Where Five Auroras Glow
summary: New York City Ballet's winter program revisits "the classics," venturing into American Ballet Theater territory. How does NYCB fare?

headline: Kraft Closes Cadbury Plant
summary: Kraft said that it will close Cadbury''s Somerdale plant by 2011, despite an earlier pledge to keep the factory open.

headline: Your View: Winter Snowstorm
summary: Heavy snowfall hit the Northeast Wednesday, disrupting school, work and travel. Here are some pictures of the snow day sent in by Wall Street Journal readers.

headline: Paulson's Gold Run Falls Short
summary: John Paulson scored big on bets against subprime mortgages. He's so far having a tough time winning over investors for his gold fund.

headline: Pakistan Needs Its Own Nuclear Deal
summary: Such a pact could finally offer the right set of carrots to ensure Islamabad's counterterror cooperation.

headline: Disney Results Reflect Consumer Caution
summary: A nascent recovery in cable-television advertising and cost-cutting at its movie studio helped boost Disney's key divisions in the latest quarter.  Overall, though, revenue and profit were essentially flat.

headline: McDonald's Sales Rise Abroad
summary: McDonald's recorded a 2.6% rise in January sales, with strength overseas offsetting weakness in the U.S.

headline: Harboring Hope For Coke Overseas
summary: Unit volumes outside North America in the fourth quarter rose faster than expected, but that growth may be tougher to manage in 2010.

headline: China Indicts 4 Rio Tinto Executives
summary: China has indicted Australian mining group's execs on charges of corruption and obtaining commercial secrets, a case that has come to symbolize dismay in foreign boardrooms over Beijing's tactics.

headline: Moody's Warns Greece
summary: One of the world's major credit-ratings firms told the Greek government that if it deviates 'even a bit' from a plan to stabilize its finances, its credit rating will be cut again.

headline: Union-Backed Nominee Blocked in Senate
summary: The nomination of union lawyer Craig Becker to the National Labor Relations Board fell short of the 60 votes needed to end a Republican filibuster.

headline: China's New Year Feasts Go Upmarket
summary: Dining out during the Chinese New Year is a relatively new concept for mainland China, and  some wonder if the rush to restaurants is killing the spirit of the holiday.

summary: With Democrats and Republicans stalemated on everything from major legislation to agency appointments, some are asking whether the institution of the Senate is broken.

headline: Newt Gingrich and John Goodman: Ten GOP Health Ideas for Obama
summary: We don't need to study lawsuit reform for one minute longer.

headline: Chance of Real Reform Slipping Away
summary: The Financial Services Authority begins the difficult task of searching for a new chief executive following the resignation of Hector Sants.

headline: Oil Gains on Speculation of Greece Rescue
summary: A winter storm and forecasts of colder-than-normal weather in the U.S. also gave crude a boost.

headline: Greece Grapples With Tax Evasion
summary: Athens's attempts to clamp down on tax evasion, which costs Greece an estimated €15 billion a year, have proven to be a more-challenging task than officials thought.

headline: China's Exports Grew in January
summary: Chinese exports surged in January, but year-earlier data was hit by a collapse in global demand and the timing of Chinese New Year.

headline: A Growing Obsession: Rare Seeds
summary: Some gardeners skip the glossy seed catalogs and turn to seed exchanges, which frequently offer unusual varieties of plants not typically found in catalogs.

headline: Ai Weiwei: Google Gives Us Hope
summary: If China can remain powerful though it limits freedom of speech, what kind of monster will it become?
